<TD colspan='2' class='navbox-list navbox-odd hlist9' style='width:100%;padding:0px'>
<DIV style='padding:0em 0.25em'><A href='/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War' title='MexicanAmerican War'>MexicanAmerican War</A>  <A href='/wiki/Taos_Revolt' title='Taos Revolt'>Taos Revolt</A>  <A href='/wiki/Cortina_Troubles' title='Cortina Troubles'>Cortina Troubles</A>  <A href='/wiki/Las_Cuevas_War' title='Las Cuevas War'>Las Cuevas War</A>  <A href='/wiki/San_Elizario_Salt_War' title='San Elizario Salt War'>San Elizario Salt War</A>  <A href='/wiki/Garza_Revolution' title='Garza Revolution'>Garza Revolution</A>  <A href='/wiki/Yaqui_Uprising' title='Yaqui Uprising'>Nogales Uprising</A>  <A class='mw-selflink selflink'>Mexican Revolution</A>  <A href='/wiki/Border_War_(1910%E2%80%9319)' title='Border War (191019)'>Border War</A>  <A href='/wiki/Bandit_War' title='Bandit War'>Bandit War</A></DIV>

<P>The <B>United States involvement in the <A href='/wiki/Mexican_Revolution' title='Mexican Revolution'>Mexican Revolution</A></B> was varied and seemingly contradictory, first supporting and then repudiating Mexican regimes during the period 1910-1920.<SUP id='cite_ref-Friedrich_Katz_1981,_p._563_1-0' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-Friedrich_Katz_1981,_p._563-1'>[1]</A></SUP> For both economic and political reasons, the U.S. government generally supported those who occupied the seats of power, whether they held that power legitimately or not. A clear exception was the <A href='/wiki/French_Intervention_in_Mexico' class='mw-redirect' title='French Intervention in Mexico'>French Intervention in Mexico</A>, when the U.S. supported the beleaguered liberal government of <A href='/wiki/Benito_Ju%C3%A1rez' title='Benito Jurez'>Benito Jurez</A> at the time of the <A href='/wiki/American_Civil_War' title='American Civil War'>American Civil War</A> (1861-1865). Prior to <A href='/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson' title='Woodrow Wilson'>Woodrow Wilson</A>'s inauguration on March 4, 1913, the U.S. Government focused on just warning the Mexican military that decisive action from the U.S. military would take place if lives and property of U.S. nationals living in the country were endangered.<SUP id='cite_ref-oimnp_2-0' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-oimnp-2'>[2]</A></SUP> President <A href='/wiki/William_Howard_Taft' title='William Howard Taft'>William Howard Taft</A> sent more troops to the US-Mexico border but did not allow them to intervene in the conflict,<SUP id='cite_ref-uqyyzbv_3-0' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-uqyyzbv-3'>[3]</A></SUP><SUP id='cite_ref-uooqzv_4-0' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-uooqzv-4'>[4]</A></SUP> a move which Congress opposed.<SUP id='cite_ref-uooqzv_4-1' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-uooqzv-4'>[4]</A></SUP> Twice during the Revolution, the U.S. sent troops into Mexico.<SUP id='cite_ref-5' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-5'>[5]</A></SUP> la The U.S. recognized the government of <A href='/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz' title='Porfirio Daz'>Porfirio Daz</A> in 1878, two years after Daz's coup d'tat brought him to power. Daz's long rule of Mexico brought close economic cooperation between the two countries, especially since Daz imposed political order that allowed business to flourish. In 1908, however, Daz gave an interview to a U.S. journalist, <A href='/wiki/James_Creelman' title='James Creelman'>James Creelman</A>, in which Daz stated he would not run for re-election in 1910; the statement gave rise to politicking of potential candidates. Daz reversed himself, ran for re-election, and jailed the leading opposition candidate, <A href='/wiki/Francisco_I._Madero' title='Francisco I. Madero'>Francisco I. Madero</A>. Mexican revolutionaries prior to the 1910 events had sought refuge on the U.S. side of the border, a pattern Madero continued. He escaped Mexico and took refuge in San Antonio, Texas and called for nullification of the 1910 elections, himself as provisional president, and revolutionary support from the Mexican people. His <A href='/wiki/Plan_of_San_Luis_Potos%C3%AD' title='Plan of San Luis Potos'>Plan of San Luis Potos</A> did spark revolutionary uprisings, particularly in Mexico's north. The U.S. stayed out of the unfolding events until March 6, 1911, when President <A href='/wiki/William_Howard_Taft' title='William Howard Taft'>William Howard Taft</A> mobilized forces on the U.S.-Mexico border. "In effect this was an intervention in Mexican politics, and to Mexicans it meant the United States had condemned Daz.<SUP id='cite_ref-6' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-6'>[6]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Although the United States appears to have pursued an inconsistent policy toward Mexico, in fact it was the pattern for the U.S. "Every victorious faction between 1910 and 1919 enjoyed the sympathy, and in most cases the direct support of U.S. authorities in its struggle for power. In each case, the administration in Washington soon turned on its new friends with the same vehemence it had initially expressed in supporting them."<SUP id='cite_ref-Friedrich_Katz_1981,_p._563_1-1' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-Friedrich_Katz_1981,_p._563-1'>[1]</A></SUP> The U.S. turned against the regimes it helped install when they began pursuing policies counter to U.S. diplomatic and business interests.<SUP id='cite_ref-7' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-7'>[7]</A></SUP></P>
<P>When Daz was forced to resign in 1911 and <A href='/wiki/Francisco_I._Madero' title='Francisco I. Madero'>Francisco I. Madero</A> was elected president in October 1911, the U.S. president was a <A href='/wiki/Lame_duck_(politics)' title='Lame duck (politics)'>lame duck</A>. The <A href='/wiki/U.S._Ambassador_to_Mexico' class='mw-redirect' title='U.S. Ambassador to Mexico'>U.S. Ambassador to Mexico</A>, <A href='/wiki/Henry_Lane_Wilson' title='Henry Lane Wilson'>Henry Lane Wilson</A> was initially sympathetic to the new regime, but quickly came into conflict with it. Ambassador Wilson conspired with General <A href='/wiki/Victoriano_Huerta' title='Victoriano Huerta'>Victoriano Huerta</A> to oust Madero. The United States government under newly inaugurated president <A href='/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson' title='Woodrow Wilson'>Woodrow Wilson</A> refused to recognize Huerta's government.</P>
<P>Under President Wilson, the United States had sent troops to <A href='/wiki/United_States_occupation_of_Veracruz' title='United States occupation of Veracruz'>bomb and occupy Veracruz</A>. President Wilson's government recognized the government of <A href='/wiki/Venustiano_Carranza' title='Venustiano Carranza'>Venustiano Carranza</A> in 1915, which allowed arms from the U.S. to flow to Carranza's forces. When former Carranza ally, <A href='/wiki/Pancho_Villa' title='Pancho Villa'>Pancho Villa</A> attacked the border town of Columbus, New Mexico in 1916, the <A href='/wiki/United_States_Army' title='United States Army'>U.S. Army</A> under Gen. <A href='/wiki/John_J._Pershing' title='John J. Pershing'>John J. Pershing</A> pursued him in a punitive mission, known as the <A href='/wiki/Pancho_Villa_Expedition' title='Pancho Villa Expedition'>Pancho Villa Expedition</A>. The U.S. failed in the main objective of that raid, which was to capture Villa. Carranza forced the U.S. to withdraw across the border.</P>

<H2><SPAN class='mw-headline' id='Anglo-American_attitudes_and_U.S._diplomacy_in_Latin_America'>Anglo-American attitudes and U.S. diplomacy in Latin America</SPAN><SPAN class='mw-editsection'><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>[</SPAN><A href='/w/index.php?title=United_States_involvement_in_the_Mexican_Revolution&action=edit&section=1' title='Edit section: Anglo-American attitudes and U.S. diplomacy in Latin America'>edit</A><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<DIV role='note' class='hatnote navigation-not-searchable'>Main article: <A href='/wiki/Latin_America%E2%80%93United_States_relations' title='Latin AmericaUnited States relations'>Latin AmericaUnited States relations</A></DIV>
<DIV class='thumb tleft'>
<DIV class='thumbinner' style='width:222px;'><A href='/wiki/File:Free_from_Spanish.jpg' class='image'><IMG alt='' src='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Free_from_Spanish.jpg/220px-Free_from_Spanish.jpg' width='220' height='261' class='thumbimage' srcset='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Free_from_Spanish.jpg/330px-Free_from_Spanish.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Free_from_Spanish.jpg/440px-Free_from_Spanish.jpg 2x' data-file-width='1239' data-file-height='1469' /></A>
<DIV class='thumbcaption'>
<DIV class='magnify'><A href='/wiki/File:Free_from_Spanish.jpg' class='internal' title='Enlarge'></A></DIV>
1914 cartoon by <A href='/wiki/John_T._McCutcheon' title='John T. McCutcheon'>John T. McCutcheon</A> illustrates the United States liberated former Spanish colonies from their oppressor<SUP id='cite_ref-8' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-8'>[8]</A></SUP> (<I>Chicago Tribune</I> 1914)</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P>U.S. foreign policy toward Latin America was to assume the region was the sphere of influence of the U.S., initially articulated in the <A href='/wiki/Monroe_Doctrine' title='Monroe Doctrine'>Monroe Doctrine</A>. In the <A href='/wiki/Roosevelt_Corollary' title='Roosevelt Corollary'>Roosevelt Corollary</A> to the Monroe Doctrine, President <A href='/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt' title='Theodore Roosevelt'>Theodore Roosevelt</A> asserted the United States' right to intervene militarily in the region to restore order if in the U.S. view a nation could not or would not do it itself. Thus there was a long history of U.S. intervention in Latin America prior to the Mexican Revolution.</P>
<P>Underpinning these U.S. foreign policies was the assumption that Latin American countries and Latin Americans themselves were lesser. Many Protestant Anglo-Americans believed Catholic Latin Americans were the antithesis of all they themselves represented;<SUP id='cite_ref-9' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-9'>[9]</A></SUP> Latin Americans were seen to be lazy to Anglo-American industriousness, sluggish to their progress, violent to their peaceful, and genetically debased. These attitudes originated in Catholic Spain's colonial-era political rivals, the Protestant English, who articulated anti-Spanish rhetoric, collectively known as the "<A href='/wiki/Black_Legend' title='Black Legend'>Black Legend</A>".<SUP id='cite_ref-10' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-10'>[10]</A></SUP><SUP id='cite_ref-11' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-11'>[11]</A></SUP> Protestant Anglo-Americans believed Spanish Americans dangerously misguided with their "anti-Christ" Pope.<SUP id='cite_ref-12' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-12'>[12]</A></SUP> One political cartoon during the Mexican Revolution expressed the opinion that former Spanish colonies were only able to advance as they had, due to U.S. intervention.</P>
<DIV class='thumb tleft'>
<DIV class='thumbinner' style='width:222px;'><A href='/wiki/File:Mexico_on_treadmill.jpg' class='image'><IMG alt='' src='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Mexico_on_treadmill.jpg/220px-Mexico_on_treadmill.jpg' width='220' height='279' class='thumbimage' srcset='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Mexico_on_treadmill.jpg/330px-Mexico_on_treadmill.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Mexico_on_treadmill.jpg/440px-Mexico_on_treadmill.jpg 2x' data-file-width='1239' data-file-height='1570' /></A>
<DIV class='thumbcaption'>
<DIV class='magnify'><A href='/wiki/File:Mexico_on_treadmill.jpg' class='internal' title='Enlarge'></A></DIV>
Mexico's fruitless pursuit of progress, where "lots of energy [is] expended but [there is]no discernible forward progress."<SUP id='cite_ref-13' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-13'>[13]</A></SUP> It suggests that until Mexico willingly forgoes violence (the pistol) and anarchy (the torch), they will remain stagnant. (<I>San Francisco Examiner</I> 1913)</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P>The press in the U.S. portrayed Mexicans as innately violent and consistently missing opportunities for advancement, as seen in a 1913 <I><A href='/wiki/San_Francisco_Examiner' class='mw-redirect' title='San Francisco Examiner'>San Francisco Examiner</A></I> cartoon. Rather than considering the Revolution as a legitimate means of forcing change, it served merely to reinforce the perception of lawless Mexicans. Many contended it was only through dictator <A href='/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz' title='Porfirio Daz'>Porfirio Daz</A> that Mexico had previously been kept out of chaos.<SUP id='cite_ref-14' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-14'>[14]</A></SUP> Land redistribution undertaken by Mexican revolutionary Pancho Villa were condemned as "offer[ing] evidence...of the barbarity of Mexican politics,"<SUP id='cite_ref-Britton,_John_1995_15-0' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-Britton,_John_1995-15'>[15]</A></SUP> to which President <A href='/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson' title='Woodrow Wilson'>Woodrow Wilson</A> replied, "the revolution was out of control and...only U.S military intervention could stabilize [the state]."<SUP id='cite_ref-Britton,_John_1995_15-1' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-Britton,_John_1995-15'>[15]</A></SUP> Constant oversight by the U.S. is effectively depicted in a cartoon where watchful American cannon "eyes" are directed on Mexico.<SUP id='cite_ref-16' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-16'>[16]</A></SUP></P>
<DIV class='thumb tright'>
<DIV class='thumbinner' style='width:222px;'><A href='/wiki/File:US_cannon_eyes.jpg' class='image'><IMG alt='' src='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/US_cannon_eyes.jpg/220px-US_cannon_eyes.jpg' width='220' height='231' class='thumbimage' srcset='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/US_cannon_eyes.jpg/330px-US_cannon_eyes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/US_cannon_eyes.jpg/440px-US_cannon_eyes.jpg 2x' data-file-width='1239' data-file-height='1299' /></A>
<DIV class='thumbcaption'>
<DIV class='magnify'><A href='/wiki/File:US_cannon_eyes.jpg' class='internal' title='Enlarge'></A></DIV>
The United States are ever watchful over the presumed chaos in Mexico<SUP id='cite_ref-17' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-17'>[17]</A></SUP> (<I>Chicago Tribune</I> 1913)</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P>These ideas led to the belief that the United States ought to militarily resolve the situation, reinforced by the second motivating factor of industrial interests in Mexico. Indeed, eighty percent of all investment linked to the railroads were attributed to the US, leading many to conclude, "by the dawn of the new century, the United States controlled the Mexican economy."<SUP id='cite_ref-18' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-18'>[18]</A></SUP> The railroads, mining and consolidated cash-crop farms were all designed to maximize American interests.<SUP id='cite_ref-19' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-19'>[19]</A></SUP></P>
<P>US corporations were thus alarmed at the possibility of radical resource redistribution and elimination of the status quo previously maintained by Diaz, and demanded that their interests be secured. This fear was fanned with that under the <A href='/wiki/Mexican_Constitution_of_1917' class='mw-redirect' title='Mexican Constitution of 1917'>Mexican Constitution of 1917</A>, the national government would be able to regulate foreign-owned operations.<SUP id='cite_ref-20' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-20'>[20]</A></SUP> Many deemed that "Mexico...was the doorway to all of Latin America's riches, but <I>only</I> if the neighbor remained under U.S economic tutelage."<SUP id='cite_ref-21' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-21'>[21]</A></SUP> The U.S. government's intervention would merely be safeguarding its interests and continuing its "informal imperialism" whereby threats of military involvement and economic pressures were used to keep Mexico in line with U.S. goals.<SUP id='cite_ref-22' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-22'>[22]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class='mw-headline' id='Diplomatic_relations'>Diplomatic relations</SPAN><SPAN class='mw-editsection'><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>[</SPAN><A href='/w/index.php?title=United_States_involvement_in_the_Mexican_Revolution&action=edit&section=2' title='Edit section: Diplomatic relations'>edit</A><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<P>Daz opened Mexico to foreign investment of Britain, France, Germany, and most especially the United States, creating the conditions of "order and progress" that promoted Mexico's modernization. <A href='/wiki/Mexico-United_States_relations' class='mw-redirect' title='Mexico-United States relations'>Mexico-United States relations</A> during Daz's presidency were generally strong, although he began to strengthen ties with Great Britain, Germany, and France to offset U.S. power and influence.<SUP id='cite_ref-ReferenceA_23-0' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-ReferenceA-23'>[23]</A></SUP> U.S. President <A href='/wiki/William_Howard_Taft' title='William Howard Taft'>William Howard Taft</A> recognized the role that Daz played in transforming Mexico, saying "Certainly no people have made greater relative progress than the Mexican people have made under the administration of Porfirio Daz...[he] has done more for the people of Mexico than any other Latin American has done for any of his people; ...the truth is they need a firm hand in Mexico and everybody realizes it."<SUP id='cite_ref-24' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-24'>[24]</A></SUP> Mexico was extremely important to U.S. business interests and Taft saw Daz as key to protecting those investments. Taft met Daz in person on the U.S.-Mexico border in 1909, an historic event in itself since it was the first trip of a sitting U.S. president to Mexico. It was a way for the U.S. to signal its continuing support of Daz, despite his advancing age. Taft was pragmatic, saying "we have two billions American capital in Mexico that will be greatly endangered if Daz were to die and his government go to pieces."<SUP id='cite_ref-Schoultz,_p._238_25-0' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-Schoultz,_p._238-25'>[25]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Despite the importance of Mexico to U.S. business interests and the long border between the two countries that could make the U.S. vulnerable to unrest in Mexico having repercussions in the U.S., the U.S. had "a history of incompetent diplomatic representation." According to one scholar, the Taft administration's appointment of <A href='/wiki/Henry_Lane_Wilson' title='Henry Lane Wilson'>Henry Lane Wilson</A> as ambassador "continued the tradition of incompetence."<SUP id='cite_ref-Schoultz,_p._238_25-1' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-Schoultz,_p._238-25'>[25]</A></SUP></P>
<P>During the presidency of <A href='/wiki/Porfirio_D%C3%ADaz' title='Porfirio Daz'>Porfirio Daz</A>, documents conveyed from the U.S. Consulate in Mexico kept the <A href='/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State' title='United States Secretary of State'>Secretary of State</A> in <A href='/wiki/Washington,_D.C.' title='Washington, D.C.'>Washington, D.C.</A> informed about Mexican affairs. The Secretary of State told President Taft of the buildup to possible regime change in Mexico, when Daz was unable to control rebellions in various areas of Mexico. Initially, Taft did not want to intervene but wanted to keep the Daz government in power to prevent problems with business relations between the two countries, such as the sales of oil between Mexico and the United States.</P>
<H3><SPAN id='The_U.S._and_the_overthrow_of_Madero.2C_1912-1913'></SPAN><SPAN class='mw-headline' id='The_U.S._and_the_overthrow_of_Madero,_1912-1913'>The U.S. and the overthrow of Madero, 1912-1913</SPAN><SPAN class='mw-editsection'><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>[</SPAN><A href='/w/index.php?title=United_States_involvement_in_the_Mexican_Revolution&action=edit&section=3' title='Edit section: The U.S. and the overthrow of Madero, 1912-1913'>edit</A><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<DIV role='note' class='hatnote navigation-not-searchable'>Main article: <A href='/wiki/Ten_Tragic_Days' title='Ten Tragic Days'>Ten Tragic Days</A></DIV>
<P>U.S. Ambassador to Mexico H.L. Wilson helped to plot the February 1913 <A href='/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat' title='Coup d'tat'>coup d'tat</A>, during the <A href='/wiki/Ten_Tragic_Days' title='Ten Tragic Days'>Ten Tragic Days</A> (<I>la decena trgica)</I>, which overthrew Francisco I. Madero. However, the Ambassador might have done this without the explicit approval of <A href='/wiki/Lame_duck_(politics)' title='Lame duck (politics)'>lame duck</A> President Taft, but Ambassador Wilson had secured the support of the foreign diplomatic corps in Mexico, especially the British, German, and French envoys, for the coup and lobbied for U.S. recognition of the new head of state, General <A href='/wiki/Victoriano_Huerta' title='Victoriano Huerta'>Victoriano Huerta</A>.</P>
<H3><SPAN class='mw-headline' id='U.S._and_Huerta_regime_1913-14'>U.S. and Huerta regime 1913-14</SPAN><SPAN class='mw-editsection'><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>[</SPAN><A href='/w/index.php?title=United_States_involvement_in_the_Mexican_Revolution&action=edit&section=4' title='Edit section: U.S. and Huerta regime 1913-14'>edit</A><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<DIV role='note' class='hatnote navigation-not-searchable'>See also: <A href='/wiki/Tampico_Affair' title='Tampico Affair'>Tampico Affair</A>, <A href='/wiki/Ypiranga_incident' title='Ypiranga incident'>Ypiranga incident</A>, and <A href='/wiki/United_States_occupation_of_Veracruz' title='United States occupation of Veracruz'>United States occupation of Veracruz</A></DIV>
<P>Woodrow Wilson was inaugurated president in March 1913, but the coup d'tat in Mexico was an established fact, with the democratically elected president Madero murdered and his family in exile. President Wilson recalled Ambassador Wilson to Washington and later replaced him. President Wilson was horrified at the murders of President Madero and Vice President Pino Surez and breaking from long-standing practice to recognize de facto regimes did not recognize the Huerta as the legitimate head of the Mexican government. A series of rebellions broke out in Mexico against Huerta's regime, especially in the North (Sonora, Chihuahua, and Coahuila), and continuing fighting in Morelos under <A href='/wiki/Emiliano_Zapata' title='Emiliano Zapata'>Emiliano Zapata</A>. Unlike the brief rebellions that helped bring Madero to power in 1910-11, Mexico descended into civil war. However, the involvement of the U.S.in larger conflicts with its diplomatic and economic rivals in Mexico, particularly Great Britain and Germany, meant that foreign powers affected the way the Mexican situation played out.<SUP id='cite_ref-ReferenceA_23-1' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-ReferenceA-23'>[23]</A></SUP></P>
<P>When U.S. agents discovered that the German merchant ship, the <I>Ypiranga</I>, was carrying arms to Huerta's regime, President Wilson ordered troops to the port of <A href='/wiki/Veracruz' title='Veracruz'>Veracruz</A> to stop the ship from docking. The U.S. did not declare war on Mexico city but the U.S. troops carried out a skirmish against Huerta's forces in Veracruz. The <I>Ypiranga</I> managed to dock at another port, which infuriated Wilson.</P>
<P>On April 9, 1914, Mexican officials in the port of <A href='/wiki/Tampico,_Tamaulipas' class='mw-redirect' title='Tampico, Tamaulipas'>Tampico, Tamaulipas</A>, arrested a group of U.S. sailors  including at least one taken from on board his ship, and thus from U.S. territory. After Mexico refused to apologize in the terms that the U.S. had demanded, the U.S. navy bombarded the port of Veracruz and <A href='/wiki/United_States_occupation_of_Veracruz' title='United States occupation of Veracruz'>occupied Veracruz</A> for seven months. Woodrow Wilson's actual motivation was his desire to overthrow Huerta, whom he refused to recognize as Mexico's leader;<SUP id='cite_ref-26' class='reference'><A href='#cite_note-26'>[26]</A></SUP> the <A href='/wiki/Tampico_Affair' title='Tampico Affair'>Tampico Affair</A> did succeed in further destabilizing Huerta's regime and encouraging the revolutionary opponents. The <A href='/wiki/ABC_nations' class='mw-redirect' title='ABC nations'>ABC Powers</A> (Argentina, Brazil, and Chile) arbitrated, in the <A href='/wiki/Niagara_Falls_peace_conference' title='Niagara Falls peace conference'>Niagara Falls peace conference</A>, held in Ontario, Canada, and U.S. troops left Mexican soil, averting an escalation of the conflict to war.</P>
<H3><SPAN id='1916.E2.80.931917'></SPAN><SPAN class='mw-headline' id='19161917'>19161917</SPAN><SPAN class='mw-editsection'><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>[</SPAN><A href='/w/index.php?title=United_States_involvement_in_the_Mexican_Revolution&action=edit&section=5' title='Edit section: 19161917'>edit</A><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<DIV role='note' class='hatnote navigation-not-searchable'>Main articles: <A href='/wiki/Border_War_(1910-1919)' class='mw-redirect' title='Border War (1910-1919)'>Border War (1910-1919)</A> and <A href='/wiki/Pancho_Villa_Expedition' title='Pancho Villa Expedition'>Pancho Villa Expedition</A></DIV>
<P>An increasing number of border incidents early in 1916 culminated in an <A href='/wiki/Battle_of_Columbus_(1916)' title='Battle of Columbus (1916)'>invasion of American territory</A> on 8 March 1916, when <A href='/wiki/Pancho_Villa' title='Pancho Villa'>Francisco (Pancho) Villa</A> and his band of 500 to 1,000 men raided <A href='/wiki/Columbus,_New_Mexico' title='Columbus, New Mexico'>Columbus, New Mexico</A>, burning army barracks and robbing stores. In the United States, Villa came to represent mindless violence and banditry. Elements of the <A href='/wiki/13th_Cavalry_Regiment_(United_States)' class='mw-redirect' title='13th Cavalry Regiment (United States)'>13th Cavalry regiment</A> repulsed the attack, but 14 soldiers and ten civilians were killed. Brig. Gen. <A href='/wiki/John_J._Pershing' title='John J. Pershing'>John J. Pershing</A> immediately organized a <A href='/wiki/Pancho_Villa_Expedition' title='Pancho Villa Expedition'>punitive expedition</A> of about 10,000 soldiers to try to capture Villa. They spent 11 months (March 1916  February 1917) unsuccessfully chasing him, though they did manage to destabilize his forces. A few of Villa's top commanders were also captured or killed during the expedition.</P>
<P>The <A href='/wiki/7th_Cavalry_Regiment_(United_States)' class='mw-redirect' title='7th Cavalry Regiment (United States)'>7th</A>, <A href='/wiki/10th_Cavalry_Regiment_(United_States)' title='10th Cavalry Regiment (United States)'>10th</A>, <A href='/wiki/U.S._11th_Armored_Cavalry_Regiment' class='mw-redirect' title='U.S. 11th Armored Cavalry Regiment'>11th</A>, and 13th Cavalry regiments, <A href='/wiki/U.S._6th_Infantry_Regiment' class='mw-redirect' title='U.S. 6th Infantry Regiment'>6th</A> and <A href='/wiki/U.S._16th_Infantry_Regiment' class='mw-redirect' title='U.S. 16th Infantry Regiment'>U.S. 16th Infantry Regiments</A>, part of the <A href='/w/index.php?title=U.S._6th_Field_Artillery&action=edit&redlink=1' class='new' title='U.S. 6th Field Artillery (page does not exist)'>U.S. 6th Field Artillery</A>, and supporting elements crossed the border into Mexico in mid-March, followed later by the <A href='/wiki/5th_Cavalry_Regiment_(United_States)' class='mw-redirect' title='5th Cavalry Regiment (United States)'>5th Cavalry</A>, <A href='/wiki/U.S._17th_Infantry_Regiment' class='mw-redirect' title='U.S. 17th Infantry Regiment'>17th</A> and <A href='/wiki/24th_Infantry_Regiment_(United_States)' title='24th Infantry Regiment (United States)'>24th Infantry Regiment (United States)</A>, and engineer and other units. Pershing was subject to orders which required him to respect the sovereignty of Mexico, and was further hindered by the fact that the Mexican government and people resented the invasion. Advance elements of the expedition penetrated as far as <A href='/wiki/Parral,_Chihuahua' title='Parral, Chihuahua'>Parral</A>, some 400 miles (640a0km) south of the border, but Villa was never captured.</P>
<P>The campaign consisted primarily of dozens of doughnut skirmishes with small bands of insurgents. There were even clashes with Mexican Army units; the most serious was on 21 June 1916 at the <A href='/wiki/Battle_of_Carrizal' title='Battle of Carrizal'>Battle of Carrizal</A>, where a detachment of the <A href='/wiki/10th_Cavalry_Regiment_(United_States)' title='10th Cavalry Regiment (United States)'>10th Cavalry</A> was nearly destroyed. War would probably have been declared but for the critical situation in Europe. Even so, virtually the entire regular army was involved, and most of the National Guard had been federalized and concentrated on the border before the end of the affair. Normal relations with Mexico were restored eventually by diplomatic negotiation, and the troops were withdrawn from Mexico in February 1917.</P>
<H3><SPAN id='1918.E2.80.931919'></SPAN><SPAN class='mw-headline' id='19181919'>19181919</SPAN><SPAN class='mw-editsection'><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>[</SPAN><A href='/w/index.php?title=United_States_involvement_in_the_Mexican_Revolution&action=edit&section=6' title='Edit section: 19181919'>edit</A><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<DIV role='note' class='hatnote navigation-not-searchable'>Main article: <A href='/wiki/Battle_of_Ambos_Nogales' title='Battle of Ambos Nogales'>Battle of Ambos Nogales</A></DIV>
<P>Minor clashes with Mexican irregulars, as well as Mexican Federales, continued to disturb the U.S.-Mexican border from 1917 to 1919. Although the <A href='/wiki/Zimmermann_Telegram' title='Zimmermann Telegram'>Zimmermann Telegram</A> affair of January 1917 did not lead to a direct U.S. intervention, it took place against the backdrop of the Constitutional Convention and exacerbated tensions between the USA and Mexico. Military engagements took place near <A href='/w/index.php?title=Buenavista,_Sonora&action=edit&redlink=1' class='new' title='Buenavista, Sonora (page does not exist)'>Buenavista, Sonora</A>, on 1 December 1917; in <A href='/w/index.php?title=San_Bernardino_Canyon&action=edit&redlink=1' class='new' title='San Bernardino Canyon (page does not exist)'>San Bernardino Canyon</A>, Chihuahua, on 26 December 1917; near <A href='/wiki/La_Grulla,_Texas' title='La Grulla, Texas'>La Grulla, Texas</A>, on 9 January 1918; at Pilares, Mexico, about 28 March 1918; at the town of <A href='/wiki/Battle_of_Ambos_Nogales' title='Battle of Ambos Nogales'>Nogales</A> on the SonoraArizona border on 27 August 1918; and near <A href='/wiki/El_Paso,_Texas' title='El Paso, Texas'>El Paso, Texas</A>, on 16 June 1919.</P>
<DIV class='thumb tright'>
<DIV class='thumbinner' style='width:352px;'><A href='/wiki/File:Mexican_War_Service_Campaign_Streamer.png' class='image'><IMG alt='' src='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Mexican_War_Service_Campaign_Streamer.png/350px-Mexican_War_Service_Campaign_Streamer.png' width='350' height='27' class='thumbimage' srcset='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Mexican_War_Service_Campaign_Streamer.png/525px-Mexican_War_Service_Campaign_Streamer.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Mexican_War_Service_Campaign_Streamer.png/700px-Mexican_War_Service_Campaign_Streamer.png 2x' data-file-width='2443' data-file-height='187' /></A>
<DIV class='thumbcaption'>

Mexican War Service campaign streamer</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<H2><SPAN class='mw-headline' id='Foreign_mercenaries_in_Mexico'>Foreign mercenaries in Mexico</SPAN><SPAN class='mw-editsection'><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>[</SPAN><A href='/w/index.php?title=United_States_involvement_in_the_Mexican_Revolution&action=edit&section=7' title='Edit section: Foreign mercenaries in Mexico'>edit</A><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<DIV class='thumb tright'>
<DIV class='thumbinner' style='width:302px;'><A href='/wiki/File:Americans-villa.png' class='image'><IMG alt='' src='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1d/Americans-villa.png/300px-Americans-villa.png' width='300' height='195' class='thumbimage' srcset='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/1/1d/Americans-villa.png 1.5x' data-file-width='424' data-file-height='276' /></A>
<DIV class='thumbcaption'>
<DIV class='magnify'><A href='/wiki/File:Americans-villa.png' class='internal' title='Enlarge'></A></DIV>
Members of <A href='/wiki/Pancho_Villa' title='Pancho Villa'>Pancho Villa</A>'s American Legion of Honor</DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P>Many adventurers, ideologues and <A href='/wiki/Filibuster_(military)' title='Filibuster (military)'>freebooters</A> from outside Mexico were attracted by the purported excitement and romance of the Mexican Revolution. Most mercenaries served in armies operating in the north of Mexico, partly because those areas were the closest to popular entry points to Mexico from the U.S., and partly because <A href='/wiki/Pancho_Villa' title='Pancho Villa'>Pancho Villa</A> had no compunction about hiring <A href='/wiki/Mercenary' title='Mercenary'>mercenaries</A>. The first legion of foreign mercenaries, during the 1910 <A href='/wiki/Francisco_Madero' class='mw-redirect' title='Francisco Madero'>Madero</A> revolt, was the <I>Falange de los Extranjeros (Foreign Phalanx)</I>, which included <A href='/wiki/Giuseppe_Garibaldi_II' title='Giuseppe Garibaldi II'>Giuseppe ("Peppino") Garibaldi</A>, grandson of the famed Italian unifier, as well as many American recruits.</P>
<P>Later, during the revolt against the <A href='/wiki/Ten_Tragic_Days' title='Ten Tragic Days'>coup d'tat</A> of <A href='/wiki/Victoriano_Huerta' title='Victoriano Huerta'>Victoriano Huerta</A>, many of the same foreigners and others were recruited and enlisted by <A href='/wiki/Pancho_Villa' title='Pancho Villa'>Pancho Villa</A> and his <A href='/wiki/Divisi%C3%B3n_del_Norte' title='Divisin del Norte'>Divisin del Norte</A>. Villa recruited Americans, Canadians and other foreigners of all ranks from simple infantrymen on up, but the most highly prized and best paid were machine gun experts such as <A href='/wiki/Sam_Dreben' title='Sam Dreben'>Sam Dreben</A>, artillery experts such as <A href='/wiki/Ivor_Thord-Gray' title='Ivor Thord-Gray'>Ivor Thord-Gray</A>, and <A href='/wiki/Physician' title='Physician'>doctors</A> for Villa's celebrated <I>Servicio sanitario</I> medic and mobile hospital corps. There is little doubt that Villa's Mexican equivalent of the <A href='/wiki/French_Foreign_Legion' title='French Foreign Legion'>French Foreign Legion</A> (known as the "Legion of Honor") was an important factor in Villa's successes against Huerta's <A href='/wiki/Federal_Army' title='Federal Army'>Federal Army</A>.</P>
<H2><SPAN class='mw-headline' id='U.S._military_decorations'>U.S. military decorations</SPAN><SPAN class='mw-editsection'><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>[</SPAN><A href='/w/index.php?title=United_States_involvement_in_the_Mexican_Revolution&action=edit&section=8' title='Edit section: U.S. military decorations'>edit</A><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<DIV class='thumb tleft'>
<DIV class='thumbinner' style='width:202px;'><A href='/wiki/File:MexSerMedals.jpg' class='image'><IMG alt='' src='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8e/MexSerMedals.jpg/200px-MexSerMedals.jpg' width='200' height='199' class='thumbimage' srcset='//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/8e/MexSerMedals.jpg/300px-MexSerMedals.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/8/8e/MexSerMedals.jpg 2x' data-file-width='342' data-file-height='341' /></A>
<DIV class='thumbcaption'>
<DIV class='magnify'><A href='/wiki/File:MexSerMedals.jpg' class='internal' title='Enlarge'></A></DIV>
<A href='/wiki/Mexican_Service_Medal' title='Mexican Service Medal'>Mexican Service Medal</A></DIV>
</DIV>
</DIV>
<P>The U.S. military awarded the <A href='/wiki/Mexican_Service_Medal' title='Mexican Service Medal'>Mexican Service Medal</A> to its troops for service in Mexico. The streamer is yellow with a blue center stripe and a narrow green stripe on each edge. The green and yellow recalls the <A href='/wiki/Aztecs' class='mw-redirect' title='Aztecs'>Aztec standard</A> carried at the <A href='/wiki/Battle_of_Otumba' title='Battle of Otumba'>Battle of Otumba</A> in 1520, which carried a gold sun surrounded by the green plumes of the <A href='/wiki/Quetzal' title='Quetzal'>quetzal</A>. The blue color alludes to the <A href='/wiki/United_States_Army' title='United States Army'>United States Army</A> and refers to the <A href='/wiki/Rio_Grande' title='Rio Grande'>Rio Grande</A> separating Mexico from the United States.<SUP class='noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact' style='white-space:nowrap;'>[<I><A href='/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed' title='Wikipedia:Citation needed'><SPAN title='This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2015)'>citation needed</SPAN></A></I>]</SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class='mw-headline' id='See_also'>See also</SPAN><SPAN class='mw-editsection'><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>[</SPAN><A href='/w/index.php?title=United_States_involvement_in_the_Mexican_Revolution&action=edit&section=9' title='Edit section: See also'>edit</A><SPAN class='mw-editsection-bracket'>]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<UL>
<LI><A href='/wiki/Mexican_Revolution' title='Mexican Revolution'>Mexican Revolution</A></LI>
